Title: Herbivore dung, a forgotten source of Eurotialean fungi
Abstract:
Coprophilous fungi are a group of saprotrophic organisms
with a great diversity. The physico-chemical characteristics of the
herbivore dung combined with the level of fungal adaptation to different
substrates offer the perfect setting for discovering new taxa. This
study focused on the identification of Eurotialean ascomycetes isolated
from 130 dung samples collected in different Spanish localities. A total
of 165 isolates of Eurotialean fungi (i.e. 60 Aspergillus and 105
penicillium-like) were studied. The isolates were preliminary identified
by morphology and sequencing of β-tubulin (BenA) gene. New taxa were
characterized by multi-gene sequence analysis using BenA, the internal
transcribed spacer (ITS), calmodulin (CaM), and RNA polymerase II second
largest subunit (RPB2) genes, and a detailed morphologic study. Using
this polyphasic approach and following the genealogical concordance
phylogenetic species recognition concept (GCPSR), we proposed two new
genera Pseudopenicillium and Penicillago in family Aspergillaceae, and
23 new species, including ten Aspergillus, six Penicillium and four
Talaromyces.
